text: After relocating to another nation, I've developed social anxiety. In contrast, my experience in my home country is not as daunting as it was in other countries, and I often feel anxious about going out with friends.

Many times, I refuse to venture out and interact with people in cities or urban areas. I have a strong distaste for social interactions at school and dislike the presence of strangers. My tendency to reject this behavior helps me cope with my personal life's challenges on the job.

Could someone provide some guidance on how to swim in the right direction without being compelled into the same lane with others? I've been struggling with it and wondering where my throat should be resting after swimming, but it seems like it's not too severe.

My experience has been worse, as it feels like everyone who does something nice in a school or social setting is either watching me do it and thinking negatively about myself, which I despise; or constantly talking about things that people say to me.

After a few years, I had the majority of my spine fused. However...I live in southeastern New York and my family has high-risk type 2 diabetes. Due to this, people always stare at me and act like they can't run around without me. I hate running public time so much, and I don'T exaggerate when I say I'd rather be skipped than ran over or served out punishment than do it myself.

The reason I'm experiencing this behavior is possibly due to my thinness, as per a friend. My friends have pointed out that I look like someone is trying to hide me by pretending to hug my arms and not swing around. It's frustrating, because even though I am 22 years old, I still struggle to walk like - which is one of the worst symptoms of social anxiety.

Living in a home where only I and my boyfriend share bedrooms and living with them is stressful for me. Worse yet, there are no plans to move in or even attend work-related interviews due to fear of being fired.

My mind goes into overdrive when I'm asked to do something for someone else, like a job or homework. This can lead to unrealistic expectations and potential consequences such as people laughing at me without my knowledge. However, the opposite is true even when it comes down to forcing myself to go outside for stretches of time.

I'm really into running, but my fear of people makes it a little more difficult than running. I used to love drinking tea, which was always comforting for me when I was younger and had smelt of smoke from the clothes.
When I'm out walking with my dog, I often see people of my age or younger individuals who may be interested in me, even if they are completely invested in our social circle.

The presence of others makes me feel extremely self-conscious and uneasy, and the only times when this happens are during periods of confinement where I cannot interact with people. Whenever I leave my room feeling insecure and unable to act like myself.

While walking alone without a friend, I experience self-consciousness and anxiety. This causes me to move at heightened speed in public areas rather than taking shortcuts on busy streets; do I suffer from social anxiety or simply like being alone? My primary concern is the possibility of meeting people who may not recognize me even if I leave my friend's home after some time due to fear of missing them

Despite knowing some of my online friends from well over 1.5 years, I feel uncomfortable when speaking with them and often pretend to be too quiet while typing. This has only made it worse lately, as I also despise going out because of the negative memories I have of being outdoors since childhood (my sister used to say that I couldn't go outside anymore).

Even after five years, my instinctively familiar response to walking away was one of thinking I heard someone speak and putting on some make-up as if they were looking at me. This was still the case five more years later, even though I graduated from high school this year and felt nervous about walking where people are usually found lying down. I went to a soccer team, but quit because of name-calling that wasn't cool.

It's easy to overlook my own insecurities, such as abandonment issues like depression and social anxiety. Additionally: I feel too dependent on my boyfriend, struggle with loneliness and isolation due to attachment issues that can be challenging for both of us.

When I got up to go out of sight, that was a huge load off my shoulders.’ Although I am still at uni it is about 12 months later and the weight loss has been amazing (I am now like any other young adult male although slightly skinny because I enjoy running) but there's just this feeling with me...

Doing parkour or any extreme sport can be dangerous, as is SA. I have a history of falling over twice in the past two months, the first time when my ankle sprain caused me to experience an injury (I grade). Although I was unaware of this before it happened and began to suffer from it, I eventually found out.

It's embarrassing that I can't even ask for a job when I feel like begging for help. Additionally, I don'T want to be in clubs or go out alone because I never find someone to talk to and I am uncomfortable with it.

As I am surrounded by people from my high school acquaintances, as well his father who told me "that's not cool." I have had enough of the last few years of my life spent longing to leave the military. Due to tendonitis in both knees (I can't do it anymore), and walking everywhere on foot (which is painful) but others are still hopeful that this will change my situation.
It would be creepy for a 6'5" guy to sit alone in secluded park. My therapist is suggesting me to walk and chill out, but I am concerned people will think it would hurt my feelings as well.
Despite meeting new faces and having no interesting stories, my lack of knowledge about Twitter's identity and the potential for social awkwardness is one reason why I avoid going out.

Besides, I suffer from anxiety when dealing with close relatives. If we go out, even if we do something to eat or drink, my body will stop excitating and I experience frequent vomiting due to this. I also worry about many things that come up in my head every day, and 90% of people will also vomit unless they are outside.

I haven’t been out much. Just recently when i moved in with my parents, I was surprised by how much better I looked but some things like my face are unmanageable and that is just an excuse to keep going outside... It’s just a constant cycle of self-consciousness which makes me feel uncomfortable sitting inside all day long.
Despite my eagerness to swim, I'm struggling with low self-confidence and anxiety. How can I overcome these challenges and stay comfortable in my own home?

It appears that I am unable to penetrate the depths and attempt something more profound. For the past two months, I have been doing my usual routine, which involves not going out for lunch or taking pictures with anyone except for myself; leaving only when someone has me on the verge of disturbing them...It gives me a sense of hope that this is what's needed in these challenging times.
Although my new puppy has helped me feel better, I still feel like I need to urinate when someone is talking to it. Are there any other treatments or therapies that you've tried that have helped?

After smoking or sitting in on the floor, I am overwhelmed by people and find myself standing in the back of the pit. Despite feeling uncomfortable, it is difficult to give up during this time due to my new surroundings.

It seems like I'm exhausted from all the brain activity, where my mind is constantly engaged in arguing and debating. I have made the conscious decision to stop caring about what I want to do but feel that my body will always repeat these words and actions without any apparent reason.

I'm in a difficult situation where my school is taking me for an exam, and I wanted to play soccer alone because I don't like running. The city has tens of thousands of people who play on ice, so I decided it's strange that I can'nt run around doing anything with other people while still being healthy.
Even though it's only my second week, I still cant bear to go to class and feel scared. Missing classes always makes me fear going to the next one.

Whenever I'm walking outside, I can hear people laughing and I worry that they might be mocking me. Although this was unassuming before or after, these thoughts have become more intrusive in recent times.
Despite living in an area that is unforgiving, I have to take my two dogs for walks each day. This has made me feel like a lunatic and has caused me undue hardship over the years.

I feel anxious when I walk outside due to the fact that everyone drives right by. This is why it's a daily occurrence for me to have to go out on my regular school day, and I'm not sure how many people would be okay with feeling uneasy or uncomfortable in places like New York.

At first, there were no issues with eye contact, pleasing others through snaps, feeling self-conscious in public settings such as socializing and being seen by other people. Nevertheless after starting high school at 14, I began to experience anxiety that didn't seem to stop me over the past six or seven years ago.

Given my lack of acquaintance, I am hesitant to venture out alone in the city and would appreciate someone offering guidance. The current workplace environment is unfriendly, and it's difficult to find anyone who can relate to me now that I have started working there.
Even with verbal and nonverbals, I didn't encounter any issues outside of school. Instead, it made me feel isolated due to my lack of social connections compared to other students in Europe.

The moments I spent outside for the entire day and sitting in front of a computer for hours every day are so nostalgic that I miss them too. Additionally, I recall feeling euphoric after spending hours on my bike with friends and resting while playing video games.
I am told this will make me feel good eventually. But when I go out every day - and have been doing a lot of it for years, I just don't really know what the point is/how.

Recently, I applied to various job positions in the retail industry and now my anxiety is mounting as people only wait for me to hear back from them. The reality is that many employers look at their experience, but since I am 22 years old, they assume I will be unemployed. Despite this, it seems like I cannot travel or explore new places without feeling exhausted, which makes some individuals skeptical about hiring me.
My tendency to make plans, run errands and go out for walks or trips has led me to underestimate my anxiety levels.

Every day for the past 3 years, I have to attend my college classes without conversing with anyone, then return home early to finish school or attend movies. I'm unable to overcome my fear of socializing and duet around alone has left me feeling depressed.
With no friends to speak of and fear for my safety, I feel depressed in my own back garden and avoid speaking to strangers. Any suggestions on how to handle this situation would be appreciated.

Although I'm on the path to recovery in California, my social anxiety is still a concern. While it was nice to be back at home after work, I felt like leaving things behind and couldn't do anything special (I stayed at the hotel before going back to San Francisco). When I return home, however, Social anxiety gets me nervous too, and I often get angry or provoke others, even when I don'

Walking on the sidewalk is something I do, but I also feel uncomfortable. My partner gets angry when I don't look comfortable and has a hard time accepting that my body language may be awkward or unintelligent.

Two weeks ago, I was invited to a barbecue and now my feet are abnormally white and I have scholiosis due to the presence of stranger friends and concerns about people trying to swim with me in the pool.

I'm struggling to overcome the challenges of transitioning from high school to college. While I understand the negative energy in life, I do feel like I can relate and find comfort in my own skin rather than a strong woman role model. Additionally, social media criticism is having repercussions for me as I struggle with being bisexual at times and trying to balance my personal life with my romantic feelings.

As a work-related individual who experiences constant fear, anxiety, and discomfort while exiting the train, I'm curious about whether others feel secure and content in hiding when they reach the back of the platform.
My body is so thin, people make fun of me and I don't want to see my face in the front yard. It hurts when others judge me for being rude and not empathetic towards them; it doesn'T help that!
Being a driver is an incredible feat. I practice my skills by doing reversing and driving on busy roads in the morning. Today, I decided to drive on if not ICE today.

I am unsure why I enjoy going out, which may be due to my preference for staying at home rather than going. I suspect this is partly due in part to anxiety, as I find myself spending time at the gym and park every day instead of going outside.

When I live with friendly neighbors, my gardening efforts are hindered by the constant attention from those around me. Despite being reminded of my own struggles, it feels like an eternity before SA becomes apparent.

After leaving camp, I struggle to leave due to my fear of being alone and experiencing panic attacks during trips. Consequently: While I've only been staying with this group for the past week, all of us who were accepted there are some pretty amazing people even in our social circle, which is great!
I am immediately nervous when leaving my house, and my anxiety is now crippling. Whenever people look at me or cars pass by, I feel uneasy.

When I went on car rides, I felt judged and judgeted by people. Walking with others during school breaks was a source of intense anxiety for me. Although I never wanted to be alone in public, it still bothers me because of the loneliness I experienced.
The constant pressure of living in the past and experiencing trauma is a source for me to seek help, even though I try to push myself outside my comfort zone.

Despite quitting my friends, I haven't seen anyone in 2-3 years and stopped leaving the apartment. My poor health and obesity have made me feel self-conscious, which has led to physical disengagement and abandonment. She leaves groceries and water for me once a week to avoid starving me outside; she doesn's not even mind dropping things that need to be sacrificed for her own good.

I am drained from the routine of daily life, including fearing awkward exits and social outbursts. I also struggle with feeling uninterested or lacking excitement when friends are around me at work, school, or home.

When I am in the presence of numerous people and enjoy exploring beaches, cafes/barrel/restaurants, etc. During conversations with friends or family about topics that are important to me, I tend to get carried away and look up at others who are also laughing and looking at me.

In addition, I experience a bizarre mental state where I feel like an obsessive wimp with my own insecurities and can look like c***n when out and about. This has led me to suffer from severe social anxiety that doesn't seem manage until it's too late.
Online anxiety is becoming more and more challenging for me, as I can't handle it. I moved out of high school at 16 and haven'ted been able to leave my family home without help.
In my 20-year stay with parents, I feel intimidated by the fact that no one seems to mind me and it makes me feel like a different person altogether.

Given my lack of education and recent social challenges, I am seeking a temporary job that will allow me to work without leaving my home. While staying with my grandmother, the stress has intensified as she is currently homeless due to ongoing trauma in my life.

I used to feel anxious about having to go out before bedtime due to the medication I was taking. I felt like everyone around me was ignoring me, and I had no desire or motivation to leave my home. Although it didn't completely cure me entirely, it made all the difference. When I got back from work or school, I began to experience symptoms such as neck tension, breathing difficulties, anxiety, depression, nervousness, fatigue, headaches, etc.

As I sit on the grass with a group of individuals, I'm about to stand up. However, now that there's hardly tense enough around me for someone to notice me and move my body forward, or even think like I might be walking in mud all day, it makes me feel uneasy.

From my teenage years, I have recognized the debilitating feeling of going outside and the anxiety of getting up to do the simplest things. This post is for someone who also has social media anxiety; while many subreddits focus on making jokes and posting memes, social anxiety is one of those topics that resonates with me most (ugh).

I am not confident about going out even though my dress and makeup and attempts at pretending are lacking in confidence. My appearance is hideous, with thick body hair that looks terrible when shaved off but doesn't transform me or change my voice.

The problem has reached a point where even those who go out of the home, like grocery shopping or Target, experience heightened anxiety and head tremors, which have become so severe that I'm willing to risk life by staying in my house.

My social life is a mess, and having friends who are socially insecure can be overwhelming. I'm struggling to make new friends even when it's difficult to find time for socializing with others outside of my own home.

Since my teenage years, I've been avoiding summers because of social anxiety. This has led me to prefer less clothing and more heat/sweat, with little comfort in the face of strangers (and being fat myself means that even sweaty clothes can be visible on your shirt).

Due to constant bullying from my teenage years and lack of employment, I quit my PG job in the 10th grade and cannot attend school anymore. My feelings have grown stronger as I am unable to leave my home without worrying about being judged or looked down upon by others who may judge me negatively even if I go out for a while.
It doesn't matter if I wear short clothing outside or in public and exercise like Phoebe from Friends.

I rarely see people in this manner and they seem to be avoiding me. On the other hand, I prefer a bike ride with fewer people and I am not keen on going out; however, my fears are too great. I don't know whether or not to tell them I feel nervous as I told them that I plan to go out in public without feeling anxious about being around others?
The thought of going to the pool with my friends makes me feel uneasy and I'm worried about missing out on socializing due to a severe fear.

I'm apprehensive because my friend and brother are also in the same room as me. My mother greets me with clevisia and I quickly run upstairs to my bedroom, where they were seen talking to strangers. They both knew Dylan, but we had never met before.

"I'm having anxiety about everything from going out with friends to going on a date with my best friend. I've been experiencing this since last summer, and it's getting worse every time." Can you help me understand what your doctor is saying?

I feel like being out in public once more due to the bullied and humiliation I experienced as a teenager. Although it was enjoyable when my friends first introduced me to outdoor activities, I can't seem to enjoy it anymore.
The thought of becoming a member of scouts and joining joggers is daunting, as I am not sure if I will be safe or have no one to turn to.
I'm feeling unmotivated to go jogging in the morning, even though I haven't exercised much and don'T frequent sports. As a result, I decided to join if possible and see - it would be wonderful!
I'm unable to walk because people keep looking at me from their vehicles while I cross an intersection. I feel like everyone is judging me, even though I don't mind taking pictures or videos of them.
Though my love for yoga is undeniable and I enjoy doing handstands, I'm not comfortable doing it alone in public, such as at the beach or on a sunny day, where people won't be aware of my intentions.
Almost ready to leave for the third day of swimming. I feel anxious when I don't feel the need to swim and am worried about my safety.

I haven't left the house since about 3 months ago, and it's been a problem. People are always watching my movements outside, even when I'm not feeling comfortable. I feel uncomfortable in social situations and often engage in awkward conversations.

After only 7 visits to a psychologist, I realized that it was an unnecessary expense. The trip back to the psychiatric clinic resulted in me being diagnosed with ADHD for years and receiving frequent medication without any recovery.

My love for running is insinuated through my lack of tolerance towards the fear of passing by others on our shared path, and I find it to be extremely distressing since no one can seem to overcome my fear or intimidate me.
Although it's okay to skip trains and run, I find that running on busy streets is a challenge for me because there are always people looking at me.

I have posted about this topic before, and although I've tried to run and walk at a slower pace, it feels awkward. Any extraneties from others are unwelcome as they don't seem appropriate or considerate. This isn'T so strange, considering I stopped running in the early days of summer because of my social anxiety about the speed of these movements.
Although buying it in a store can be scary, the most frightening thing is going to walk down to 'the market square'.

Since I have been struggling with social anxiety, it feels like I'm too afraid to be comfortable around someone I love and am unable even when it comes to communicating. We had this strange relationship where we would text every week but ended up fighting.

What are my SA obligations? This is sort of a rant post but in summary, I'm doing great at school, have friends, and enjoy spending time together. I also feel like I need to remind people that I am struggling; going out to dinner or something is interesting for someone else. It's not the same without having dated anyone before, but there must be some family involvement as well so I don't lose motivation easily.

Living in this place since moving isn't something I fully understand. Although I'm considering taking a walk, it's quite daunting to be alone and not feel comfortable doing so. I usually go out to see my doctor with someone who tends to me for several hours each weekdays.

I have a desire to swim, as per my doctor's recommendation, even though I don't possess the perfect body. Additionally, walking around with me in complete isolation is considered terrible behavior and people tend to think you are merely lonely.

Whenever there's an opportunity to look at someone in the eye, or while riding my bike or walking around, I feel like they are looking at me and making fun of me. It seems like everyone is just taking advantage of this moment even though they have only been seeing me for 10 seconds.

Personally, I prefer that activity. However, it's not something I would do anymore. Despite my fondness for swimming pools like others, the constant pitiful looks at others have made me hate them more. Thank you for your response!
Seeing people my age outside is something that always makes me anxious.

Don’t look at anyone if you walk past them. Hang in there! Just as I get very nervous around people, I try to keep my walks low profile at night (I think half the time). If you have ever noticed someone smiling and make eye contact, use the rule of thumb.

Despite being told I walk like someone else in elementary school, it's something I've been thinking about since I was a kid. It'll be difficult when you have to walk outside because people will judge me on my appearance, but sitting makes me feel more relaxed and comfortable around them as an adult.

It depends on how people perceive SAD, as I was unable to walk or interact with others because of my paranoia. If someone is struggling with basic social interactions and avoid those activities, it may be indicative of SADD or another disorder.
Walking on my bike in public feels unnatural and everyone around me is staring at us. It's not an inconvenience. Trying to throw a frisbee in front of someone I have no connection with is horrifying.

I am hesitant to walk quickly, but I do have concerns about my proper walking ability and become anxious when around people who are constantly checking on me and judging my appearance. This is why I detest going outside.
It's a constant struggle for me to have social interactions, but the overwhelming fear of leaving my house and walking in public places makes it difficult.

When I had to get out, I became uneasy and had no choice but to confront the fact that people were looking at me and possibly judging me. I also had trouble getting through the traffic noise and hearing noises outside.

Even if I go out for a walk in the rain at 3am, I'm not one to take that risk. However...being part of psychiatric groups or talking to an expert about health concerns is on the opposite end of the spectrum.

It feels like I'm too old to go out in public, but I feel like a child who could have been targeted by attackers. Even though I can travel with friends or play at the park, I still don't feel comfortable doing so.

Although I'm not sure if it will take long, I still don't feel comfortable doing it. However: after running, my anxiety doesn'estest me no way and feeling uneasy sometimes (like when running outside again). Other times (3 / 4/10) I do run backwards then turn around to go for walks or hikes but mostly that makes me anxious (also NOT comfortable) Some days get easier with out running; in other cases

As I was struggling to overcome agoraphobia during my last year of university, it started happening regularly and left the house. It's now common for people with this condition to stay in their own homes on average until they become completely ill without medical attention.

Even though I have a love for being outdoors, I find myself getting anxious while walking in my neighborhood. It seems like there's always rumors that someone will approach me and ask for money or other requests, even if it means not having any cash on hand.

My usual practice is to avoid shopping, dining out, and exploring public spaces in order not to disturb others. I have never had any communication with anyone and have been diagnosed without much research. Even small gestures like walking my dog are difficult for me. It's believed that I developed social anxiety after being picked on during my elementary school years. Since then, I hadn't spoken to anyone outside of my family for two or three months since I was diagnosed; I don'

As someone who used to suffer from severe social anxiety during ages 12-16, I was terrified of leaving my home or conversing with loved ones due to fear of danger. This condition, known as Agoraphobia, can be caused by exposure to hazardous environments such as public transportation, shopping centers and being outside the house.

One day, it was so hard that I had to leave and take a break on slouching benches by the side of the road. It felt like being stuck in utter despair. Now, with time gone by, I can look back with satisfaction. In my homeland of China, we used to walk in many different directions without any foreign assistance.

To put it mildly, I live in a Victorian-era lifestyle for most of the 20th century and have learned not to wear short clothes or dress fattishly. However, my dislikes for being too easily seen with others make me feel unsatisfied with my appearance, leading me to avoid going out at night because of social norms that suggest I am not overweight

My preference for outdoor activities is due to my extroverted nature and lack of communication with only close friends. It may seem ridiculous, but I don't mind living in the same environment as others.
You can only find the light if you search for it, and the dark unless you look for yourself.

My anxiety and some strong feelings were not extreme, but they were manageable due to the busy environment of being in a studio with thirty other people. I tried various methods such as listening or playing with toys; walking outside; watching Netflix; talking to teachers about my life; taking breaks from work; drinking water; doing breathing exercises; going to museums; and texting my boyfriend are all ways I deal with these emotions.

As I roll, a man in the parking lot calls out to see rollerblades. Unfortunately, my vision blurs and I hit rocks and fall behind bushes. I remove my roller blades from the car and walk back to my apartment where I probably spent 5 minutes before realizing I may have forgotten how to lift my feet on the steps that lead to the rear of my building.

Being in high school and having a group of 30 boys and 10 girls makes me anxious, as I don't like running for 10 seconds. I also hate the fact that my mother doesn'T love me or thinks she would kill me because it feels like we need to be together after 9 years.
Although I'm insecure about the people around me, it was a source of distress and anxiety for me.
Being a university student is making me feel overwhelmed and depressed. Additionally, I am feeling even more uneasy about having no one to share my feelings of loneliness with during the first year.
keyword: swimming,  pool, swim, swim, outside ,  walk, swimming,  pool, swimming, swimming, swimming,  pool, outside , swimming

text: It's possible that I do this with little things, like pretending to love something I'm doing during work hours.

Even though I spent countless hours on my hikes alone, the peace I found was fleeting and often seemed to have passed as thoughts of myself unraveling. When I returned from backpacker camp for 2.5 weeks, I felt isolated and avoided social situations, frequently missing meals due to loneliness caused by being so far away from home.
If my mother requests that I spend time with my family at the beach, why do I decline because of my lack of social connections?
I'm not interested in spending time with my family as I am visiting my grandma this summer. I don't have any plans to go out and spend time together, which is why I can'T do it all the time.

I'm considering going to the beach, but I feel like it's not an option. I know I can enjoy swimming, and spending 20 minutes in the water would be too much time for me; however, I don't know if there are any other options available or a more suitable approach. My fear is that I won'T go, even though I have some free time.
My decision to go swimming and spend time with my friend on Skype is a bit of skepticism, as I often feel stressed about making that last call.
As a driver, I don't want to enter vehicles without tint due to its extreme exposure. It feels unbearable and disgusting.
This sub seems like the right choice, and I'm at a loss for what to do next. After being invited to supper once, I had to leave because I felt terrible about it afterwards...

Sometimes, I feel sorry for my child because I lack the motivation to play with him or engage in social activities due a mental block between us. Additionally, participating in group activities can be problematic when it comes to our bonding.

During my one-year stint as a social worker, I was offered thousands of job opportunities but none were accepted. I went on 'The Hanging Man' course and studied Japanese language,' and even celebrated Men's day with the group after being sick for two weeks, felt very lonely among them (I broke up and started crying), so this left me feeling completely alone.

Every time I attempt activities to broaden my horizons, I encounter disappointing results. For instance, when joining a rowing team, everyone hesitates and makes me feel inferior; in fact, even though I practice regularly, it doesn't matter as much for me because of that.

At first, it felt like a break from the norm and I was relieved after running errands. However, now that's all I have left and my partner looks much better, and his physical fitness isn't affected by cold or flu-like symptoms.

Part of me wants to suck it up and be there for her, but we all know how stressful it can get. I don't know anyone from these groups who are my friends or boyfriend. He said he would come with me on this weekend (I was under 30), then I cancelled because hm doesn'T have time?

Do you feel like I'm trapped indoors most of the time? Even when going to the beach alone, I still experience feelings of sadness and loneliness. It's even more poignant when I see people my age outside enjoying their company and making memories together. This year, it'll be even worse because this is something I want so much to do in my life - especially since I don't have anyone to spend time with.

It was never a problem for me when my mom used to take me to soccer, tennis and basketball. However now that it's over I feel like playing again, the fear of trying is even more extreme as they grow older.

Engage in something that you are passionate about. Although it may seem strange, I've come to realize over time that everyone has their own problems and struggles with self-confidence, while most of those I know at 15/16 have little or no job and lack the skills to change it. This is due to my consistent struggle with walking weirdness, having an ugly face, underdeveloped jaw, running around weird, and feeling uncomfortable in public.

I wish the day was more enjoyable for me, but my anxiety causes feelings of isolation that make it difficult to walk alone. In those moments when there are few people around, I might start walking in the morning.

Social anxiety has left me with severe challenges and a challenging life situation, as I am 22f and on the autism spectrum. I haven't been outside for four years and don'T want to be seen as someone who is afraid of strangers or people that push my buttons.

Two years ago, I started attending a foreign university and left the program at the end due to enduring an abusive relationship with narcissistic individuals. After that, my relationship came to an abrupt conclusion last year after two months. I was left feeling depressed and had to apologize all over the place for being too quiet.
Would it be unusual for someone to sit alone in a park and read 'The Hunger Games'?

My preference for relaxing in parks and listening to music can be overpowering, but I'm not entirely sure if someone is trying to manipulate me or judging me based on other factors. Additionally, my night walks have made me wonder supposing I might be under some sort of influence as well. Can you suggest what nextdoorsitelooks is?

The thought of being looked down upon by others while walking outside makes me feel like I am a puppy, even though my behavior is not very different from that of other people. It's frustrating because the individuals in the car are constantly staring at me without any reason to stop looking or responding.

I would be able to apply for any job I desire without worrying about missing an interview because of my fear of not answering the phone and getting back to my boss. I could exercise at the gym, park or the grocery store, among other places, without feeling embarrassed and I might have friends.
Even though I am still interested in socializing with others, my feelings have remained unchanged. I'm uncertain whether this will change until I feel less anxious and purposeless.
In an effort to clarify my plan of getting organized for the day and going outdoors, I faced a troubling issue where I felt uneasy and could not finish anything even after walking outside.

Running has become a struggle for me in recent months, and I often wonder why this is happening when it's too late to start. However, my anxiety doesn't go away and instead, the anticipation seems unsettling.

My anxiety has been a lifelong issue, and it's caused me to feel extremely anxious about the future. I'm struggling with low-weight issues that have led to significant weight loss from overeating and lack of appetite losing due to stress (which can be very damaging). Additionally, I sometimes experience traumatic brain injuries related to socializing or being in public places without protection.

Meeting unfamiliar people and attending family events can make me anxious, which is why I tend to avoid direct eye contact and avoid social interactions with my parents. This also means that I am not comfortable with making eye contacts when I'm in a hurry.

I have a habit of overthinking my actions and situations for minutes to hours at varying intervals. For instance, I avoid going out during the day and instead go to places I need to visit. I had been in therapy for 2 months and it was the most uncomfortable experience. As he said, "I live alone in SF because I don't want to go outside."
Whilst I have a fondness for walking outside, my dislike of this activity stems from the constant attention that cars receive. I opt to use car transportation whenever possible.
My first time using an Uber and going out has just occurred. I'm 18 and trying a vape, but I have incorporated CBD or kratom into my routine to avoid nerve pain and anxiety.

After ending a toxic relationship that caused me stress, I experienced heightened anxiety and panic attacks while giving impromptu presentations to my class. I was barely able to read from my paper or understand what was happening in the room when I finally hit the big screen.
It's common for me to enjoy walking around my neighborhood and being alone, as I dislike the feeling of being constantly surrounded by people.

When there is no one around and I feel like they are peeping out of their windows or something, I literally cry uncontrollably. I also worry that my parents will overlook me when I show up at school (even though I graduated from a different high school) and assume that it's just for me to be recognized by them.

A sunny day and a dark night are both enjoyable experiences, but the anxiety that comes with going to sea for vacation makes it difficult to avoid being surrounded by people on secluded days. On another note: I love spending nights at the beach in the cold on winter nights without worrying about traffic or noise.
